text:
When Childe first arrives at Liyue Airport, he does not gawk at the picturesque mountainscapes in the distance, nor does he marvel at the crystalline clear blue sky, free from the gloomy clouds that hung over Snezhnaya all year long. 

Instead, he is busy shedding his thick parka whilst scanning the crowd huddled around the arrivals section of the airport, all waiting and holding up signs with the names of people they are picking up. To be completely honest, he feels wildly out of place with his winter clothes, bright hair, and giant worn suitcase that has Teucer’s action figure stickers plastered all over it in the most disorderly manner possible. 

Dragging his suitcase behind him—and almost running over the toes of multiple people who fix him with unrestrained glares—Childe fumbles around his pockets for his phone. Once found, he unlocks it, sitting down on a nearby bench and opening up his messaging app. He scrolls through his chats to locate his conversation with 'Guizhong', his apparent new roommate, and taps on her profile picture to get a better look at her face.

Childe furrows his brows and looks around him. There wasn’t anyone that matched her features from his quick look through the crowd.

“God,” he mutters under his breath, sending a quick i’m here, where are u into the chat and momentarily regretting the fact that they didn’t organise a specific meeting place because, wow, he thinks with another quick turn of his head, this place is huge. Childe’s afraid that if he moves away any further from where he is, he’ll end up in an entirely different pocket dimension altogether.

Fifteen minutes, two outgoing missed calls, and a scroll through the entirety of his Twitter timeline later (Viktor taking selfies during church, Ekaterina complaining about her recent blind date, the usual), and Guizhong still hasn’t replied, her dainty portrait smiling merrily from next to her previous messages. 

Childe groans and locks his phone, throwing his head back to stare at the high ceiling. There’s a baby screeching somewhere to his right, and the sound grates incessantly at his ears. 

Maybe Guizhong’s late, he reasons, or maybe her phone broke on the way here and—

Suddenly, a mess of inky black hair pops into his vision.

Childe yelps, his surprise causing him to suddenly sit up and bash his head against the stranger’s. “Ow!”

“Ah!” The stranger recoils as quickly as he appeared, holding a hand to his forehead. “I’m terribly sorry. It was not my intention to startle you.”

Childe mirrors his motion, immediately scrambling to plaster a smile across his face because this guy is… handsome, to say the very least. High cheekbones, golden irises, a messy bun of dark hair, and an alluring touch of rouge eyeliner beneath his eyes.

Oh. Huh. The airport suddenly feels very, very warm. 

“It’s okay,” Childe reassures the stranger hastily, trying to push down the flush rising on his cheeks, “It’s my fault for reacting the way I did.”

“I apologise,” the Liyuen man says again with a bow of his head and Childe is now holding his hands up and stuttering as he tries to compute the fact that maybe he’s? Getting hit on? Within thirty minutes of arriving in this country? “Not just for inducing accidental bodily harm, but for being less than punctual as well.”

“Huh?” Childe drops his hands. “What do you mean?”

“I am here to pick you up,” the stranger clarifies, his face strangely and comedically solemn for the current situation, “My name is Zhongli.”

“You mean ‘pick me up’ as in take me on a—?”

“No,” the other man deadpans, “as part of my obligation as your new roommate.”

Childe’s brain short-circuits a bit. “Huh? Sorry, but I’m waiting for a ‘Guizhong’... you must have the wrong person.”

Zhongli frowns, and Childe’s brain instantly snapshots the sight and pastes it directly into his mental dictionary next to the word ‘cute’. “Then I suppose I am the ‘Guizhong’ you are looking for, in this case.”

Childe reaches for his phone. “Wait, wait, wait, but Guizhong is a woman,” he says, showing Zhongli the woman in question’s profile picture. “And you’re…” a man. A very stunning, ‘I-would-instantly-empty-my-wallet-for-you’ type of man, but a man nonetheless, “...not exactly that.”

“I—”

Zhongli’s phone rings right at that moment, a strange little tune that Childe swears he has heard before but can’t exactly pinpoint from when. Zhongli reaches into the pocket of his fashionable trench coat, pulls out a Nokia flip phone (what the fuck) and brings it to his ear. 

“I found him,” he says without even glancing at the name on the screen. “Yes… no. No. He thinks— please stop yelling, I do not understand what you’re talking about.”

Childe stands there awkwardly, not quite able to comprehend how a man with a Burberry coat and Gucci loafers is still carrying around brick for a telecommunication device in this day and age. Reality is truly stranger than fiction.

“...Okay.” Zhongli says almost petulantly, before he hands his phone to Childe. “Here. Guizhong would like to talk with you.”

By now, Childe has begun piecing together the fact the Zhongli and Guizhong are most probably, definitely, two separate people, and that some strange miscommunication has likely occurred somewhere during the process of him just wanting to avoid being tragically homeless his new country of residence.

“Hello?” he asks into the phone. “Guizhong, right?”

“Yep!” Guizhong chirps, her voice a bit fuzzy and staticy through the outdated device. “Sorry about all the confusion! I wanted you to get acquainted with Zhongli without me being there in person, but I guess I forgot to tell you that I’m not actually, well, him, haha!”

“Er… haha,” Childe says, not sure how to respond, “it’s alright. Everything’s sorted out now, yeah?”

“I guess so. Well, cool beans,” Guizhong laughs, “I’ll meet you two at Zhongli’s apartment to help you guys set up. See you in an hour!”

“Huh? Oh, okay, b—,” the call disconnects, “—ye.”

Childe stares at Zhongli’s Nokia, feeling a little disoriented. Zhongli shoots him a look of tired solidarity. 

“For the record, I have no idea why she insisted on finding my roommate for me. I thought I was capable of doing so myself,” Zhongli explains flatly. “So you are as much of a surprise to me as I am to you.”

Childe huffs out a laugh. He can’t say he’s displeased. “A pretty good surprise then.”

Zhongli blinks in confusion, and Childe feels his heart squeeze a little. He scratches his cheek and turns his head away. “Um. Nothing, let’s go!”

 

 

 

“I do not have any mora on me,” Zhongli says quietly when they’re in front of Zhongli’s apartment, trying to pay the taxi driver the fare for the trip. 

Childe gawks, his face twisting with bewilderment. “How did you get to the airport, then?”

“The driver let me off the hook in exchange for my phone number,” Zhongli says, as if that wasn’t the sketchiest thing in the world. Childe makes a face.

“It’s alright,” he says while reaching for his wallet, “I’ll pay.”

 

 

 

Guizhong is standing in front of the elevators as they enter the foyer, dressed in a flowing white sundress and sandal heels. Her smile is warm and youthful like the afternoon sunshine. She looks almost ethereal. If Childe were a little more heterosexual, he would definitely be trying to arrange a dinner date by this point.

“Hey!” She waves, and Childe waves back, eased by her easygoing attitude, “welcome to Zhongli-xiansheng’s humble abode!” 

She gestures around the foyer—which is evidently not Zhongli’s abode, but it’s close enough. 

“Zhongli… what?” Childe asks, the local Liyuen honorific lost on him. Teyvatian may be the universal language of the world, but every nation still has its nuances. He makes himself a reminder to pick up a book on Liyuen language and customs to brush up on later.

“Please do not worry about it,” Zhongli tells him as they huddle into the elevator and he swipes his keycard for the fifth floor, “It is an honorific of respect towards one’s elder, but when Guizhong uses it, it simply serves as a way of teasing me.”

“Not my fault you walk and talk like an old man all the time,” Guizhong points out.

As Zhongli is unlocking the door to his apartment, a strange sound of scratching comes from behind the door. Before Childe can open his mouth and ask about it, the door opens and Childe is promptly greeted with a face full of brown fur.

“Morax!” Zhongli exclaims, and Childe would be swooning over how smoothly his voice flows with a bit of emotion in it if he wasn’t already busy sputtering and spitting out bits of fur from his mouth. 

Zhongli pulls the big furry lump away from his face, dangles it—a cat—by its nape and looks disapprovingly at it. “That is not how we treat guests.”

The cat… Morax, meows in response, its tail flicking side to side. It is the furriest thing Childe has ever seen in his life, and Childe is someone who has seen Viktor’s unshaved legs.

“Told you that you needed to train some manners into your fur son,” Guizhong says, helping Childe move his luggage into the apartment. “You spoil him too much.”

Childe picks the last bit of hair from his tongue before he turns towards Zhongli in disbelief. He looks at the man, looks at the cat, then looks back at the man. “‘Morax’?”

“That’s right.” Zhongli replies, bending down to let the little furry devil trot off into the apartment.

Childe watches the animal retreat around the corner before he turns back towards Zhongli. “You adopt what is possibly the fluffiest maine coon in all of Teyvat… and you decide to name it after a demon. The ruler of hell.”

Zhongli raises his eyebrows. “I do not see a problem with that.”

Childe opens his mouth to protest, before he remembers the ferocity that Morax had exhibited in launching itself onto Childe as if his face were nothing more than a shiny new squeaky toy. “...I guess so.”

 

 

 

Zhongli’s apartment is… unorthodox, for the lack of a better term. It’s very much an organised chaos more than anything—somehow managing to simultaneously tread the thin line between orderly and disorderly, between uncluttered and utterly disastrous. 

Everything is where it’s supposed to be—the television is snug against the wall, the table is placed towards the kitchen peninsula so that one is able to access the rooms in a direct route from the couch area. But everywhere Childe lands his eyes, he can spot at least ten different things in his field of vision—clusters of strange, multicoloured ores on the shelves, multiple ancient Liyuen-style calligraphy artworks hung on the walls, an ornate room divider in the corner that seems to serve no purpose other than to look pretty, frog statues made of jade sitting next to a bamboo pot plant next to a marble vase almost as tall as Childe, the list goes on…

“Where do I put my stuff?” Childe asks, still looking around the room and playing a spontaneous game of Where’s Waldo with himself, except instead of a stripey little man, he’s searching for something that would actually see practical use in everyday life.

“Over here,” Zhongli says whilst shrugging off his coat, and, wow, his waist is tiny, “in your room.”

Childe follows his new roommate into the bedroom, not exactly sure what to expect. He breathes a shallow sigh of relief when Zhongli flicks the lights on and presents him with a rather neat, albeit bare space.

“This room used to belong to Guizhong, but she had to move to the other side of the city for work,” Zhongli explains, “Now it is yours. Please feel free to customise it as you see fit.”

“You two used to live together?” Childe asks. “There’s already enough stuff in this apartment with you alone in it.”

Zhongli chuckles, the sound soft and soothing. “Guizhong had taken up much more space than me. She even converted the balcony into her mini workshop for her industrial design projects. Though I admit.. since she moved out, I may have taken up a habit of buying more than I need—”

“You started hoarding, that’s what you started doing!” Guizhong yells from the kitchen. “Me moving out was so shocking that you had to turn to material objects to fill that newly formed Guizhong-shaped hole in your heart!”

Zhongli whips his head around. “It’s not like tha—”

“I’m hurt, Zhongli-xiansheng! ” Guizhong whines with her head in the fridge as she fumbles around for something. “So now you’re saying I meant nothing to you? Not after I spent five years rooming with you? Not after I wasted my entire childhood trying to bail you out of trouble after you kept beating the snot out of the kids on our street?”

Childe can’t help but burst out laughing. Zhongli brings his hand up to rub at his temples. “I did not senselessly ‘beat the snot out’ of them. I only did so to defend you and Havria from their harassment.”

Guizhong pops her head out from behind the fridge door. “Yeah, and that was enough to get you cemented as our local thug—a tiny elementary school kid absolutely pummelling a bunch of middle schoolers.” She turns towards Childe and shoots him a wink. “If you ever run into trouble, you know who to call for backup, yeah?”

“Actually, I’m pretty good in a brawl myself,” Childe inputs, “I’d love to see if I can match hand-to-hand with xiansheng here.”

Zhongli sighs. “Not you too.”

Childe walks over to the kitchen, taking in the ingredients Guizhong paid out on the kitchen bench. “What’re these for?”

There’s a dangerous glint in Guizhong’s eyes. “A trial.”

“A trial?”

Guizhong closes the fridge. There are little souvenir magnets and sticky notes all over the door. She puts her hand on her hips and gestures towards the ingredients; tofu, rice, multiple types of proteins, and an assortment of vegetables.

Guizhong grins. “As you may or may not know,” Childe does not know, “Zhongli here is incapable of cooking.”

“I won our high school culinary competitions.” Zhongli protests under his breath, but Guizhong catches it anyway.

“Correction:” she says, “Zhongli here is incapable of cooking for himself.”

Childe snorts. “So that’s why you told me you were specifically looking for someone with ‘world class cooking skills’ on flatmate dot com?”

Guizhong claps her hands together. “Exactly! I’ve seen how well you cook already from your social media, so just think of this as an induction of sorts. If you make something that can live up to Zhongli’s picky tastes, I’ll discount your rent.”

“I thought I was the landlord here.” Zhongli walks over to them, and Guizhong shushes him with a hand over his mouth. The man crosses his arms, but makes no move to swat Guizhong away.

Childe is already rolling up his sleeves at this point, a playful smirk dancing across his lips. He is so ready for this. “No worries. Watch me wow this guy off his feet.”

Zhongli smiles from behind Guizhong’s hand, his eyes shimmering under the warm kitchen lights. “Surprise me.”

 

 

 

“Mmh! This is amazing!” Guizhong exclaims between mouthfuls of stir fry—one of the few Liyuen dishes that Childe knows how to cook—before piling more food into her bowl. “It’s even better than the stuff made by locals.”

“Thanks, that’s some pretty high praise.” Childe grins, stabbing his plastic fork into a piece of chicken. 

(Unfortunately, the trio realised too late that Childe is physically incapable of using chopsticks until dinner was almost served, which prompted Zhongli into making a dash for the nearby 7-Eleven to buy a twenty pack of plastic forks, which would hopefully last them until either Childe learns how to wield the fiddly eating utensils, or they go out to buy more environmentally friendly metal forks.)

“What’s the verdict?” Guizhong turns towards Zhongli, who is chewing slowly on a piece of xianggu and nodding approvingly.

“Good,” he says. Childe beams.

Guizhong claps her hands. “It’s settled, then! Welcome to the team!”

“What team?” Childe asks.

Zhongli looks awkwardly away from the table. Guizhong leans forward. “The ‘Helping Zhongli Be A Functional Member Of Society’ team’, of course!”

Morax takes that opportunity from the lapse in the conversation to lift his head from the cat bowl and meow in agreement.

 

 

 

Childe is in the kitchen at ass-o’-clock later that night, heating up leftovers in the microwave when he feels a presence behind him, and a warm breath ghosting across his nape. 

“Munchies?”

Childe almost springs out of his skin. “Son of a— fuck!”

Zhongli jumps back, his eyes widening. “I apologise—I didn’t intend to frighten you.”

Childe drops his combat stance. The microwave beeps. “Sorry, my fault. I overreacted.”

He takes the food out of the microwave, wincing a little when his fingers make contact with the hot pyrex container. Zhongli follows behind him to the dinner table with a question in his eyes. His hair is tied into a low, side ponytail and his face is softer from a lack of makeup. He has cat slippers on his feet. 

An entirely different sight from when Childe first saw him—tall, stoic, almost regal.

“Jet lag.” Childe answers Zhongli’s unasked query tiredly. 

“I see.”

He deflects the question back. “Why are you still up?”

Zhongli blinks slowly, looking not fully awake. “I… often wake at random hours of the night.” He replies. Childe frowns.

“That can’t be normal.”

“It has been the norm for me for years,” Zhongli says with a slight smile. “Please don’t worry about it.”

He takes a seat at the table opposite to Childe, seemingly watching his roommate eat, but Childe can already tell that he’s simply zoning out. They (read: Childe) eat in silence for a while as the clock’s hour hand slowly inches towards two in the morning. It’s a bit awkward in all honesty, mostly attributed to the fact that Zhongli has gone as still as a rock, and Childe doesn’t have much material to create a meaningful conversation from, given that he’s only really known the other man for half a day.

Morax slinks out from behind Zhongli’s bedroom door, evidently woken up by Childe’s cussing and the aroma of food. He meows and hops onto Zhongli’s lap with the grace of a dolphin despite his bulky stature, and that seems to startle his owner out of his half-asleep state.

“Oh.” He blinks. “Hungry?”

Morax rubs his head against Zhongli’s chest. Childe wishes he had his phone with him to take a picture.

After giving Morax his midnight snack and letting Childe finish his, the three of them sprawl out on the couch, letting the soft light of the television wash over them as Childe flicks through the channels and Zhongli cards his hands through his cat’s fur. 

They fall asleep just like that—National Geographic: Liyue Edition running on the screen and Morax’s cat snores drowning out those of his humans, as morning light bleeds from the tips of the mountains and into the night.

 

 

 

Over the next few days, Childe discovers a lot of things about his new roommate.

The first thing is that Zhongli is terrible at housework. The severity of this incompetence is further amplified by Morax’s unhelpful tendency to shed hair everywhere and barf up hairballs in the most obscure places. One of them being, somehow, behind the fridge. 

It’s not that Zhongli avoids his chores—in fact, he’s eager to help Childe in any way he can—but more so the fact that he simply does everything wrong: he folds the laundry, but the method is completely inefficient. He vacuums, but for some reason all the dirt on the floor flees to the sides of the nozzle rather than into it. He has no idea how to use the washing machine, or the dishwasher (currently being used as a second pantry), or a hairdryer. 

 

(“How do you not know how to use one of these?” Childe almost yells, waving the cordless hairdryer around with his hands and in general making himself a blatant safety hazard within the confines of their shared bathroom.

“The last time I tried to use it… was not a pleasant experience.” Zhongli says stiffly. Childe takes Zhongli’s hand and resolutely places the gadget onto it.

“Show me how you used it.” 

Zhongli nods. He brings the dryer up and points the end of it like a gun so that it touches Childe’s forehead—and before Childe can realise that something is fundamentally wrong with this setup, Zhongli flicks the switch for full blast and sends Childe’s head flying back into the mirror, completely K.O.ed.

Needless to say, Childe considers himself lucky that his front bangs haven’t been fried to a gingery crisp.)

 

 

The second thing Childe finds out is that Zhongli is currently doing his masters at the same university that Childe got his transfer scholarship at… which really shouldn’t have been a surprise given that they live ten minutes from said university, because why else would Zhongli be living here? 

 

(“We could get lunch together between classes,” Childe grins, perhaps a little too enthusiastically. Zhongli doesn’t seem bothered by it, judging from the smaller but no less happy smile on his face.

“Yes,” he agrees, leaning his chin on his hand, “We can.”)

 

Then Zhongli casually drops the fact that he’s actually the head of the student council, and Childe subsequently waves their lunch dates goodbye in the face of countless board meetings and leadership obligations.

 

 

(The last thing Childe finds out is that Zhongli, despite his technological incompetence and unrealistically picky tastes, is seemingly perfect in every other way.

It’s not that Childe intentionally stares at his flatmate whenever Zhongli goes off on a tangent about the industrial compounds of their toilet cleaner or fusses over the mud on Morax’s paws or sips his daily cup of green tea with the zen of a thousand monks—his eyes just. Linger.

But, well, Zhongli is objectively very attractive, and Childe is objectively very not straight, so of course it’s natural to feel some decidedly very un-roommate-y feelings in this situation, right?)

 

(…Right?)

 

 

“Childe,” Zhongli taps him on the shoulder, “I think we need to go shopping soon.”

Childe looks up from where he’s texting Tonia about sending her some of Liyue’s local beauty products. “Sure. You need me to come along, right?”

Zhongli smiles in affirmation, and Childe’s heart flips like a pancake in a teflon pan. “It would be preferable. And I’d like to use it as an opportunity to show you around the city, given that you have only recently arrived.”

Childe sits up, leaving Tonia on read. He’ll get back to her later. “When?”

Zhongli looks up at the clock, before he turns back around. “How about in fifteen minutes?”

Childe makes a face as he pulls himself up from the couch. “I think we need to work on your definition of ‘soon’.”

 

They meet a kindly elderly woman in the foyer on their way out, donning gardening gloves, a giant hat, and about three layers of sunscreen on her face.

“Childe,” Zhongli begins, picking Morax up from the floor so the little bugger won’t run around and tangle his legs together with his cat leash (because Morax needs walks, otherwise he will become fat, is what Zhongli had said, and Childe, out of the kindness of his heart, decided not to tell him that Morax already looks fat with all that fur), “This is Granny Ping, our resident gardener.”

He turns towards Granny Ping. “Granny, this is Childe, our resident… just resident.”

Childe laughs at that, taking the elderly woman’s hand and giving her a warm handshake. “Nice to meet you, I’m Zhongli’s new roommate.”

Granny Ping laughs with him, the lines of her face belying the youthful sparkle in her eyes. “What a capable young man. You are in good hands, Zhongli.”

Despite feeling like he should be the one in Zhongli’s hands—being in a new country and all—Childe raises his eyebrows and asks cheekily, “how can you tell I’m capable?”

Granny Ping takes his hand into both of her hands and runs her fingers over his knuckles. “For one, you are living with dear Zhongli here.”

Zhongli coughs.

The old woman continues. “And two, the callouses on these hands tell no lies—you are an able, hardworking young man.”

Childe stares down at his hand, his grin waning a little. There are multiple laceration scars crisscrossing up and down his fingers, the result of picking up cooking knives too young and too clumsily. The pads of his fingers are rough from the way he holds the brooms, and there’s a faint burn mark dappled across the meat of his thumb from an ironing mishap a few years back. 

“I’ve always disliked my hands,” he says, perhaps unnecessarily. 

Granny Ping looks him in the eyes and smiles back. “One day you will feel proud of them.”

 

 

“Oh,” Zhongli says at the checkout whilst peering into his very evidently empty wallet. “I forgot to bring mora.”

Childe brings his hands up to his head. “First the taxi, then the takeout yesterday, and now this.” He mutters. Thank the heavens they’re at a self-service checkout. “I’m beginning to see a concerning pattern here.”

Zhongli simply looks at him with his unmoving gaze, slim fingers still holding the wallet open, and Childe groans as he reaches into his own pocket to pull out his own wallet and fish his own card out of it. “Fine.” 

After that, they make their way outside… and find Morax engaged in a battle royale showdown with a doberman twice his size, still leashed to a pole. Zhongli promptly drops his three bags of groceries to snatch his hairy son off the ground. Morax hisses and yowls, his claws unsheathed and swiping through the air and very narrowly missing Zhongli’s bare arms.

The doberman snarls, restrained by its own leash to a separate pole. Zhongli quickly tries to untie Morax’s knotted leash before a female voice rings through the air, sharp like lightning. 

“Down!”

The dog instantly cowers, and Childe looks up to see a short woman with purple dyed hair stalking angrily in their direction.

“Did Beidou not train any manners into you?” She mutters as she frees the whimpering animal from the pole. Then she looks up. “I’m sorry—oh.”

Zhongli looks back at her, half his face obscured by angry brown fluff. 

“Hello, Keqing,” he says, muffled.

“Zhongli,” Keqing stands up. “Fancy meeting you here, I haven’t seen you at all during the break. You look well.”

Zhongli smiles, his eyes thinning. “Likewise.”

Keqing looks away and coughs, tugging her dog’s leash and sliding a strand of hair behind her ears. “I’ll see you once classes start again. Remember to email Ningguang your timetable so that we can organise a slot for our weekly meetings.”

“Of course,” Zhongli replies, walking back over to lift all three of his grocery bags with one arm before giving Keqing an awkward half-wave-not-wave. It’s tough to make big hand gestures when he’s got a cat draped over his upper arm. “Take care.”

“You too,” she says. Childe can’t help but think that this entire exchange feels very stiff.

“Who was that?” Childe asks once they’re out of earshot, but not out of sight—the woman’s gaze burns the back of his neck, following his and Zhongli’s every movement.

“A vice of the student council,” Zhongli hums, trailing his eyes over the window displays as they walk by, “We’re not particularly close, but she and I are on good terms, at the very least.”

Childe looks behind him. Keqing is still staring at them. He looks forward. “Er, yeah. I guess—huh? W-woah! Hey!” 

Someone pushes between them with such force that Childe almost topples over and drops his bags.

The stranger grunts when Childe shouts at him, before the latter looks over to Zhongli to make sure he’s alright. The older man looks back at him, slightly ruffled but fine for the most part, except for the heavy frown between his eyebrows.

”Are you okay?” he asks.

Zhongli shifts Morax from one arm to the other, presumably to ease the strain. He pauses. He pats his pocket.

“Childe,” he says slowly. “Just now, that man, he seems to have… taken my wallet—”

Childe sputters. “He what?!” 

“He reached into my pocket and took my—”

“Oh my god! Fuck, okay,” Childe lets out a few more choice Snezhnayan expletives, immediately dropping his bags to the ground. “Wait here, I’ll get it back right now—”

“Make way! Make way—!!!””

“Huh?” Childe barely gets a word out of his mouth before a flash of purple hair shoves him to the side for the second time within five minutes. “Hey! What the hell is going on!”

“Keqing?!” Zhongli exclaims, staring towards where the woman is running with her dog in the direction the thief had fled in.
